docs.lead_paragraph: Threatened with a strike in a month, Verizon Communications has a simple message for its unionized workers: Let's form a partnership so Verizon, one of the few unionized telecommunications companies, can compete in a fiercely competitive industry. But the president of Verizon's largest union said it was well-nigh impossible to take talk of a partnership seriously when management was battling unionization efforts at Verizon's wireless operations.

headline.main: Union and Verizon at Odds on Focus of Talks

docs.abstract: Verizon Communications is in tough negotiations with Communications Workers of America, which represents 75,000 Verizon workers in 12 northeastern states; seeks concessions that would help it reduce soaring health care costs, cut absenteeism and ease contractual barriers to relocating workers; union threatens walkout on Aug 2 if company does not agree to strong contractual provisions to pave way o unionize nearly 20,000 workers at Verizon Wireless, joint ventured owned 55 percent by Verizon and 45 percent by Vodafone Group of Britain; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Threatened with a strike in a month, Verizon Communications has a simple message for its unionized workers: Let's form a partnership so Verizon, one of the few unionized telecommunications companies, can compete in a fiercely competitive industry.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: PATENTS for methods of carrying out an idea have long generated controversy because they award exclusive ownership to a way of doing things, not a mechanical, electrical or chemical innovation. Patents have been granted for methods of doing surgery, business, scientific experiments, even cutting hair and brushing teeth. In 1998, after hearing a legal challenge to a patent for a way of pooling mutual fund assets, the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit ruled that methods of doing business could be patented. Since that ruling, known as the State Street Bank decision, applications for business-method patents have begun transforming the way products are created and marketed.

headline.main: Patents; Insurance protection for terrorism, divorces, frivolous lawsuits and excessive gambling losses.

docs.abstract: Entrepreneurs take lead in patenting new insurance policies, most of which they then license to large insurers; ideas include coverage for just about anything that carries risk, such as terrorism insurance, divorce insurance, insurance against frivolous lawsuits, coverage for gambling losses or foreign exchange losses and insured lottery tickets (M)
docs.snippet: PATENTS for methods of carrying out an idea have long generated controversy because they award exclusive ownership to a way of doing things, not a mechanical, electrical or chemical innovation. Patents have been granted for methods of doing surgery,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Candice S. Miller was riding high last week, flush with the glow of being a freshman Republican in the House of Representatives. On Thursday, she dipped into Washington's famous pork barrel, when the House approved a military construction bill that included $9.6 million for a new health care center at a base in her Macomb County, Mich., district. Next, in the wee hours of the morning on Friday, her party squeaked out a one-vote victory on the Medicare prescription drug benefit bill.

headline.main: Two Sides of Political Reality for New Lawmakers

docs.abstract: Article in Freshman Year series on two new members of Congress: Rep Candice S Miller, Republican who is riding high as party's legislative agenda rolls on, and Rep Raul M Grijalva, liberal Democrat who has been on losing side of a number of votes and is infuriated at way House leaders have limited Democrats' ability to offer amendments to legislation and debate their own ideas on House floor; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Candice S. Miller was riding high last week, flush with the glow of being a freshman Republican in the House of Representatives.    On Thursday, she dipped into Washington's famous pork barrel, when the House approved a military construction bill...

docs.lead_paragraph: As the recession has slowed industrial activity, Lloyd Graff has found one way to revive sales at his machine tools dealership: auctions on eBay. He has been able to find buyers for everything from $100 accessories to $55,000 precision rotary tools. It is great, he said, to reach many more customers. The only problem is the customers are far more informed about prices. ''EBay makes for a more efficient marketplace, and that leads to very compressed margins,'' Mr. Graff said. ''We just hope for a higher velocity of sales.''

headline.main: EBay Faithful Unshaken Despite Ever Slimmer Profits

docs.abstract: Ten thousand people from all 50 states and 20 countries attend eBay Live convention as sellers and buyers discuss world's largest Internet auction site; talk centers on booming business at slimmer profit margins; eBay sold $15 billion worth of goods in 2002 (M)
docs.snippet: As the recession has slowed industrial activity, Lloyd Graff has found one way to revive sales at his machine tools dealership: auctions on eBay. He has been able to find buyers for everything from $100 accessories to $55,000 precision rotary tools....

docs.lead_paragraph: A systematic effort by President Bush to enlist members of his party's conservative wing in the White House, and to champion touchstone conservative issues, has produced a unified base of support for him from this sometimes wayward faction of the Republican Party, conservative leaders say. Mr. Bush's standing among conservatives going into next year's election appears more than strong enough to withstand the strains that have emerged in recent weeks over some of his policies, including his support for providing prescription drug coverage under Medicare and for expanding the child tax credit.

headline.main: Bush Looking to His Right To Shore Up '04 Support

docs.abstract: Conservative leaders say Pres Bush has created unified base of support within Republican Party's right wing by systematically trying to enlist its members in White House and to champion touchstone conservative issues; says Bush's standing among conservatives going into next year's election appears more than strong enough to withstand strains that have emerged in recent weeks over some of his policies, including support for providing prescription drug coverage under Medicare and for expanding child tax credit; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: This spa town in the Bavarian countryside, blessed with natural hot springs with reportedly curative powers, does not resemble Fort Lauderdale or Miami Beach, but it is the rough German equivalent, the place where retirees go for their comfort and well-being. But if Bad Füssing is small compared with senior citizens' centers in the United States, it nonetheless represents a big part of the future in Germany and elsewhere in Europe, where a population that is both living longer and producing fewer children is beginning to change some of the fundamentals of both social and political life.

headline.main: An Aging Europe May Find Itself on the Sidelines

docs.abstract: Population that is both living longer and producing fewer children is beginning to change some of basics of both social and political life in Germany and elsewhere in Europe; many experts see government bids to cut pensions and other social services as harbinger of demographic shift with important implications for European societies as whole; median age is expected to rise from 37.7 to 52.3 in 2050 in Europe, compared with only 35.4 in United States, meaning European economic and military power will decline in world that is largely becoming younger; European population is shrinking as well; Europe seems to face choice of allowing more immigration or accepting less influential role in world affairs; graph of median age and fertility rate; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Joseph Piacentile, a whistle-blower in a lawsuit against Medco Health Solutions, seemed an odd partner for the Justice Department, which said last week that it was joining the plaintiffs in that suit and in a related one. The suits accuse Medco, a managed-care unit of Merck & Company, the drug manufacturer, of cheating the federal employees' health plan by driving up costs and promoting the use of expensive drugs.

headline.main: Private Sector; Checking a Whistle-Blower's Résumé

docs.abstract: Justice Department joins whistle-blower Dr Joseph Piacentile in suit charging Medco Health Solutions, Merck & Co managed-care unit, of cheating federal employees' health plan by driving up costs and promoting use of expensive drugs; federal officials say they know Piacentile pleaded guilty in 1991 to Medicare fraud; Medco denies charges (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: AS the cyclists whizzed by, they cried '' Hola!'' Apparently it is customary, on the Camino de Santiago, to greet fellow pilgrims with an ''hola'' or a ''buen camino,'' even if they are eating your dust. ''Hola,'' I called back, as cheerily as I could. My feet hurt.

headline.main: A Pilgrim, but a Tourist, Too

docs.abstract: Denise Fainberg travel article on hike along part of pilgrimage route to Santiago de Compostela in northern Spain; photos; map (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Having spent nearly a decade complaining in this and other newspapers, I am bitterly gratified that state officials are finally questioning the health insurance reforms adopted in 1992 (''The Rising Price of Getting Well,'' June 22).

headline.main: A Solution To Health Care Crisis

docs.abstract: Janice M Cauwels letter on June 22 article on New Jersey health care reforms suggests independent contractors be allowed to once again buy association-sponsored group policies

docs.lead_paragraph: The 226th annual session of the New York State Legislature ended on June 20, a day later than it was scheduled to, after a flurry of last-minute negotiations that stretched into the early hours but failed to resolve disputes over several major bills. The tempestuous finish of the regularly scheduled session capped an unusual year in which the Senate's Republican majority and the Assembly's Democratic majority banded together in May and passed a $92.8 billion budget over Gov. George E. Pataki's vetoes.

headline.main: A Summary of the Major Actions of the Legislature's 226th Session

docs.abstract: Summary of 226th session of New York State Legislature, which was notable in that Senate's Republican majority and Assembly's Democratic majority banded together to pass $92.8 billion budget over vetoes by Gov George E Pataki; perhaps most important bill passed by Legislature was statewide ban on smoking in workplace; photos (L)
